bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 29, 1942

div1.p: Hench informs Kean that Jessie Ames sent Hench a certificate of Roger Ames' yellow fever infection as well as an army paper, which referred to Ames as “yellow fever immune.” He also discusses his own impending military service.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 29, 1942
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
June 29, 1942
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I was not worried about the manuscript as it is in good
hands and the more time you and General Truby have been able to give it,
the more valuable it will be to me.

I am just answering a nice letter from General Truby and I
am taking the liberty of sending you a carbon copy. I have just been
going over some material that Mrs. Ames sent me, including a certificate
of his yellow fever infection, signed by Stark, and later another army
paper which referred to him as a “yellow fever immune”. It is too bad
that the matter wasn't cleared up at the time.

Presumably I go into service the twentieth of July for some
preliminary training. I am anxious to get at it, especially as I hear
that they have already opened Camp Carson with a temporary medical crew.
I had hoped to get in on the ground floor and start with that advantage.
All I can hope is that the army men that I meet and work with will
approach the high character of the army men whom I have met, who were
in the Cuban campain. That is very high indeed.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. The package arrived
today safe & sound
Haven't had time get to
open it.
